questions.title: Key features of the Java programming language
questions.description: Evaluate how well the candidate understands the core capabilities that distinguish Java as an enterprise language.
questions.prompt: Name and briefly explain the core features that make Java popular in modern software development.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Look for mentions of object-oriented pillars, JVM-based portability, automatic memory management, strong security, built-in multithreading, JIT performance optimizations, distributed APIs, and the breadth of the standard library.

questions.title: Explain the signature public static void main(String[] args)
questions.description: Checks whether the candidate understands why every standalone Java application defines a specific entry point.
questions.prompt: Explain what each modifier and parameter in public static void main(String[] args) represents and why the JVM requires this signature.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect an explanation that public enables JVM access, static avoids object instantiation, void indicates no return value, main is the entry name, and String[] args captures command-line arguments, ideally with a concise code snippet.

questions.title: Contrast Java with C++
questions.description: Assesses the ability to compare Java with another systems language across memory, syntax, and runtime characteristics.
questions.prompt: Describe several practical differences between Java and C++, covering memory management, platform support, language features, and performance expectations.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: A satisfactory answer contrasts garbage collection vs. manual memory management, JVM portability vs. native binaries, lack of pointers/multiple inheritance/operator overloading in Java, differences in standard libraries, expected performance trade-offs, and exception handling philosophies.

questions.title: Heap vs. stack memory in Java
questions.description: Evaluates whether the candidate can differentiate Java's runtime memory regions and their lifecycles.
questions.prompt: Explain the differences between heap and stack memory in Java, including purpose, lifetime, access patterns, and performance implications.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect details such as heap storing objects with GC lifecycle, stack storing method frames and local vars, LIFO access on the stack, global visibility of heap references, and the performance/management trade-offs between them.

questions.title: Java's platform independence
questions.description: Checks understanding of the JVM model and what “write once, run anywhere” really means.
questions.prompt: Explain how Java achieves platform independence and why JVM bytecode matters.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Look for mention of compiling to bytecode, the JVM interpreting or JIT-compiling that bytecode on any platform, and how this abstraction allows the same .class files to run unchanged across operating systems.

questions.title: Is Java purely object-oriented?
questions.description: Validates whether the candidate can reason about Java’s object model and primitive types.
questions.prompt: Clarify whether Java is considered a pure object-oriented language and justify your answer.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: A complete response notes that Java is not purely OO because primitives (int, boolean, etc.) and static contexts exist outside objects, even though wrappers and autoboxing can bridge the gap.

questions.title: Running Java without a main method
questions.description: Determines if the candidate understands modern JVM requirements for application entry points.
questions.prompt: Is it possible to run a standard Java application without a main method? Explain why or why not.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect mention that the JVM mandates main as the entry point, that earlier tricks with static blocks are no longer supported, and thus applications need a main method unless another framework (like app servers) supplies an entry.

questions.title: equals() vs == in Java
questions.description: Ensures the candidate can distinguish reference equality from logical equality.
questions.prompt: Describe the difference between the equals() method and the == operator in Java, and give an example.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Good answers explain that == compares references for objects (but values for primitives) while equals() can be overridden to compare state; many cite String examples showing two equal values but different references.

questions.title: Default values of Java variables
questions.description: Checks knowledge of how Java initializes different data types.
questions.prompt: List the default values assigned to instance variables of primitive types, chars, booleans, and object references in Java.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect mention of numeric types defaulting to zero (0 or 0.0), char to '\u0000', boolean to false, and object references to null, noting that local variables must be explicitly initialized.

questions.title: Instance vs. local variables
questions.description: Assesses understanding of scope, lifetime, and storage for different variable types.
questions.prompt: Differentiate between instance variables and local variables in Java across scope, lifetime, default initialization, and memory location.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Candidates should mention that instance variables live in heap with object lifetime, have default values, and are accessible via object references, while local variables reside on the stack, exist only within a method/block, and must be initialized manually.

questions.title: String vs. StringBuffer vs. StringBuilder
questions.description: Evaluates knowledge of mutability, thread safety, and performance trade-offs in Java string handling classes.
questions.prompt: Compare String, StringBuffer, and StringBuilder in terms of mutability, thread safety, and usage scenarios.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect answers stating String is immutable, StringBuffer is mutable and thread-safe via synchronization, StringBuilder is mutable but not synchronized, with related performance considerations and example use cases.

questions.title: What is an I/O stream?
questions.description: Confirms understanding of Java I/O abstractions and how data flows between programs and external resources.
questions.prompt: Define an I/O stream in Java and describe typical sources/destinations that streams abstract.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Look for definitions that describe streams as ordered sequences of data connecting programs to files, sockets, devices, etc., with mention of input vs. output streams and how they standardize read/write operations.

questions.title: Why Java does not expose pointers
questions.description: Tests understanding of Java's safety model regarding memory access.
questions.prompt: Explain why Java avoids exposing raw pointers and how references provide a safer abstraction.
questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect mention that hiding pointers prevents unsafe memory access, buffer overflows, and leaks; references plus managed memory/garbage collection strike a balance between safety and productivity.
